key_insight: A multimodal deep learning model that jointly uses molecular sequence, 3D structure and biochemical properties can predict immunogenicity accurately while providing interpretable signals for hypothesis generation.
problem_solved: Current immunogenicity prediction methods often rely on single data modalities (sequence only) or produce black-box outputs; this work addresses the need for integrated, biologically grounded and interpretable immunogenicity forecasts.
method: Integrate three input modalities — primary sequence, structural (3D) information and biochemical/physicochemical features — into a single predictive model.
Use structure-aware encoders and multimodal fusion followed by an interpretable prediction head that provides residue- or region-level attribution for immunogenic drivers.
Train and validate the model on experimental immunogenicity datasets to enable hypothesis generation and downstream design decisions.
impact: Enables AI/ML practitioners to build more biologically faithful and interpretable molecular predictors, improving the reliability of immunogenicity screening and accelerating vaccine and therapeutic design workflows.
visual_elements: Schematic of the multimodal architecture showing sequence, structure and biochemical inputs converging into a fusion module and interpretable output.

paper_title: ImmunoStruct enables multimodal deep learning for immunogenicity prediction
paper_authors: Kevin Bijan Givechian, João Felipe Rocha, Chen Liu, Edward Yang, Sidharth Tyagi
